required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Single Doses GSK159797 On Patient Safety And Lung Function In Patients With Mild To Moderate Asthma
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomised, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Dose Ascending Crossover Study to Assess the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacodynamics and Pharmacokinetics of Inhaled GSK159797 Delivered by Dry Powder Inhaler in Mild to Moderate Asthmatic Subjects

brief_summary.textblock: This study was designed to test safety aspects and effects on lung function of a new dry powder version of GSK159797 for asthmatic subjects to inhale. This will allow comparison with previous studies which have only used inhalation of the drug as a vapour.

primary_outcome.measure: Safety and tolerability including blood test results, effects on the heart, pulse rate and blood pressure, and side effects.

secondary_outcome.measure: Effects on the lung at 12 and 24hrs Effects on the heart, blood pressure and pulse rate at 8hrs Changes in the amount of glucose and potassium in the blood 4 and 8hrs Amount of drug in the body (blood and urine).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- Subjects with mild to moderate stable asthma but no other lung problems.
- Male subjects or females who are not able to get pregnant (e.g. post-menopausal or surgically sterile).
- Non-smokers.
- Subjects that show a measurable improvement in the function of their lungs after a single dose of salbutamol.
Exclusion criteria:
- Any significant illness.
- Subjects with heart problems.
- Subjects who have had a cold or chest infection 2-4 weeks prior to the study.
- Subjects who take medication for their asthma, or other conditions, not compatible with the study.

link.description: Researchers can use this site to request access to anonymised patient level data and/or supporting documents from clinical studies to conduct further research.

patient_data.ipd_description: Patient-level data for this study will be made available through www.clinicalstudydatarequest.com following the timelines and process described on this site.
